document.text: Wounded in the gun battle and charged with the crime is Frank Mayberry, 47 of Evergreen. It appears that Tucker was slain on the back porch of the residence in Evergreen in which he and his wife, her mother, and her brother, May berry lived. This shooting apparently occurred sometime after 10 oclock Friday night. Called to the scene from his home in Appomattox, Dr. Christian was on an errand of mercy. From a re construction of the events, it appears that the popular young doctor was shot as he approached the door of the -house. Christians body was found on the walk to the house, and removed only after a terriffic gun battle between the posse and Mayberry. Nearly two hours passed between the shooting of Tucker and the flni arrest, of May- berry- Mayberry was Yelled by a shotgun blast near a garage hide out from which he had fired from 30 to 50 shots from a pistol and a shotgun at the surrounding officers. Mayberry was given medical treat ment here and sent to Rlctnond Saturday morning. His wounds are said not to be serious. The midnight sounding of sirens and the use oi flares to light up the scene attracted the attention of a sizeable gathering of spectators and details of the tragedy have been the topic of interest here since. Funeral services for the victims were held Monday. Serviced for Mr. Tucker were conducted from the Evergreen Baptist Chunch, by the pastor, the Rev. D. L. Bailey. Mili tary services were conducted by the grave by American Legion Post 104. Burial was in the Evergreen Ceme tery. Funeral services for Dr.Christlan were held here Monday at 11 A. M., from Appomattox Court House Pres byterian Church, conducted by his pastor, Dr. Twyman Williams, as sisted by Dr. C. A. Collins, Jr., and the Rev. B. T. Price. A great concourse of friends gath ered for the services. An outpour ing of floral tributes and messages of condolence bore testimony to the esteem in which th1 young physician and his family are held. Son of Dr. D. A. Christian, Jr. the physician began his practice here following service in the Navy during World War II. He occupied the office his father had used for a generation of service to the people of this area. Affectionay known as Young Doctor David, he endeared himself to the public by his skill as a physician and the charm of his personality. He was serving as a member of the Appo mattox Town Council and recently organized a group here to further the cause of physical education at the Appomattox school. As a mark of respect, local busi ness places closed during the funeral hour. A movement has begun to have an appropriate memorial in his hon or. A meeting of friends was held this week to organize a memorial movement, and another meeting will be held Monday night. Dr. Christian is survived .by his wife, the former Louise Campbell of Staunton three children, Mary, 6 Pamela, 4, and David A. Christ ian, IV, 7 months his father, Dr. David A. Christian, Jr and the fol lowing sisters and brother Mrs. George L. Koos, of Tangent, Ore- - gon Mrs. Worth Harris, La Crosse, Florida Mrs. Harold E. Thompson, Jr. Staten Island, New York Mrs. W. J. Byerly, of El Paso, Texas . Mrs. John E. Cox, Jr., Fall Rive  I  Continued on .Page r .-

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: We present below a statement from the family of Dr. David A Christian, Jr. The tragic death of Dr. David A. Christian, III, Feb. 25 saddened the oemmunity and was the occasion of widespread expres sions of respect for the family I have had expressions of sym pathy from hundreds of people  many, many cards and every imag inable thing that could be done to show the love that everyone had for my son, David A. Christian, III. Words cannot express, pen ox pencil trace, the deeds that have been done in the love of the com munity, and the desire to lighten the load on me and my sons wife and childrenGod walks in a mys terious way His wonders to per formHe plants His footsteps on the sea and rides upon the storm. I do not doubt Gods wisdom and I pray that I may meet my son in Heavenand I ask the prayers of everyone to help me.  My last great want, absorbing all Is, when beneath the sod, And summoned to ray final call, The mercy of my God. Extract of A Letter By A Friend of the Family I am thankful that we do not have to understand these strange

document.text: Tuesday of this week, Sunset at Appomattox, a documentary film,, produced in Hollywood, had its pre miere before a blue ribbon list of dignataries in Lynchiburg. Nearly 200 saw the advance showing, and came away thrilled at the splendid reproduction of the events of April 9, 1865 at Appomattox. At a dinner at the Virginian Ho tel preceding the showing, Represen tative W. M. Abbitt was toastmaster. Fred Helsaibeck, vice-mayor of the City of Lynchburg, gave the invoca tion. Distinguished guests, including educators and historians, were intro duced. Major-General U. S. Grant, III, grandson of Ulyssis S. Grant, spoke briefly, praising the peace at Appomattox reuniting the na tion. Rev. Richard H. Lee, a kinsman of R. E. Lee, spoke in the same vein. William A. Hart, director of adver tising, E. I. DuPont Company, pro ducers of Sunset at Appomattox, told the story of how the film, was made. Conrad L. Wirth, Director, National Park Service, thanked the DuPont Company for this documen tary contribution. Sunset at Appomattox will be televised nationally on DuPonts Cavalcade of America program, over ABC network, Tuesday night, Oct. 20. We understand WLVA - TV, in Lynchburg carries this program at 730 P. M. Attending the luncheon and the Premiere ... from Appomattox were r Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. T. Moses, Judge and Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Mr. and Mrs. D. T. Robert son, Mr. and Mrs. George Abbitt, Jr. C. W. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Burke, Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Moses, Jr. Mrs. Charles Crawley, Mrs. C. M. Stratton, Mr, and Mrs. Calvin H. Robinson, Miss K u li a Ferrell, Mrs. E. Carroll Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. H. OBrien, G. B. document.text: TO BUY OR SELL USE OUR CLASSIFIED COLUMN Church N Dr. David A. Christian has been practicing medicine in Appomattox County for foitv years. On May 20 he observed his. 68th birthday and that date also marked the ap proximate lorthie. anniversary of his service as a beloved physician here. Interviewed at hjs home last we. K-end, Ur. Christian took time out to recall many interesting ex periences of four secvice-crowded decades. Ilia grandfather, William D. Christian was a doctor. Dr. W. D. Christian graduated at Hampden- Sydney and studied medicine at the University of Pennsylvania. He is remembered by many . of the older citizens of the county,.- And Dr. Christians father, David A. Christian, Sr. was Appomattox County Judge for 15 years. He also served as statistician in the State Board of Education. The present Dr. Christian com pleted his medical study at the Medical College of Virginia in 1908. It is interesting to note that in 1904 and 1905, he was a rural mail carrier on a route out from the Vera post office. In May, 1908, he set up his of fice as a young doctor. document.text: The Solicitation Committe for the Christian Memorial Fund met last night and is pleased to report that approximately 6,000 has been raised in cash and pledges. All committee members want to to take this chance to thank each and everyone for their wonderful support in this project. The Memorial Quarter drive in the schools has been very successful. The children and teachers have giv en full cooperation, with excellent results to date. Blueprints for the proposed Me morial Building should be ready in the near future. Anyone having suggestions as to a suitable site for the Memorial Building. Contact Dr. C. G. OBrien, chairman of the Memorial Board of Directors. The committee is pleased to an nounce that the Appomattox High School Athletic Association is spon soring a Variety Show about May 1st, and the proceeds are to go to the Memorial. This is a splendid ges ture on the part of the students and coaches. Contributions may be maield to Dr. David A. Christian III Me morial Fund, Box 47,7, Appomattox, Va.

document.text: The saga of events following the shooting of two men at Evergreen on the night of Feb. 25, ground to its final chapter here yesterday, as Frank Mayberry was sentenced to a second life term in the state peni tentiary. Judge J. W. Flood order ed the second life term, after May berry entered a plea of guilty to the shooting of his brother-in-law, Jack Tucker. The trial yesterday was in contrast to the one two weeks ago, when packed court rooms heard, the defendant receive a life imprison ment sentence after two days of le gal battle on indictment for the slaying of Dr. David A. Christian, III. Dr. Christian had gone to the Mayberry - Tucker home in Ever green Feb. 25 on an errand of medi cal duty, only to be shot as he

document.text: the recent Model General Assembly in Richmond. These two students expressed their appreciation for having been given the opportunity to attend this youth assembly, and spoke briefly of the benefits deriv ed from the three-day session. iMrs. Crawley, as a delegate to the annual state convention of the Federation of Virginia Womans Clubs, gave an interesting report of the constructive sessions she at tended. She said during her associ ation there with members of other clubs, she learned new ideas and worthwhile projects which could be adopted by the local club. Mrs. Flood also attended this convention with Mrs. Crawley. Mrs. David A. Christian, III treasurer, gave a detailed report of the clubs financial transactions for the past two years. This report was accepted as read. At the request of Mrs. Thelbert M. Trent, chairman of the Conserva tion dpartment, it was agreed to sponsor a delegate to the Nature Study Camp to be held at Holliday Lake this summer. The selection of this delegate will be made by Mrs. Trent and her commitee. The fine arts committee report was given by Mrs. Richard Janatka, chairman. She cited the number -of art exhibits put on display and the showing of the work of local talent. She also gave a report of the book reviews, and by whom given. Mrs. R. M. Mann, chairman of the welfare department of the club, told of the activities of club members in civic drives and their willingness to cooperate in this wide scope of work. The budget for the coming year was read by the treasurer, and was adopted. A report of the ways and means committee was submitted by Mrs. H. A. Gurney, chairman. This re port showed the untiring efforts of the committee members and the fine results. document.text: The most pressing need of the hour in Appomattox is to devise some inducement to add another doctor to our communitys staff. The passing of the beloved young David A. Christian, III, gives us occasion to observe that by and large, this community has overworked and underpaid its medical men. Young doctors have scant incentive to go to rural areas, with the long hours, endless driving, and small compen sation, in comparison to what is offered in larger centers. These things the hours, the driv ing, and small compensation, are the handicaps we must face. But face them we must, for Ap pomattox cannot ocntinue to over burden the medical men we do have available. Our best thinking must be done to seek the solution to this pressing problem. Appeals must be made to the medical schools and placement groups, but to back up those appeals we must be prepared with data. A long -range solution to this problem, which is but typical of the same situation all over the country, is for the armed forces to release to civilian service some of the young doctors they are holding in service. Vast numbers of the civilian doctors are over-age, but simply cannot retire. Young doctors arent getting the experience in general practice they used to get they are spending their first years as doctors in the armed services as specialisits and many have no taste for general rural practice when they complete their tours of duty. Again, our medical schools must be expanded, and more young men induced to go through the years of study and preparation for a career as doctors. But these long range sugestions do not help us right now. Let us cooperate so far as possible to lighten the load on our doctors, and use what means may be avail able to induce another young doctor to settle in our midst.

document.text: The Hon. David A . Christian assumes charge this week of the Chase City Progress. The Judge enters the field of journalism with tbe best wishes of a host of friends. We regret that Appomattox county is to lose so valuable a citizen, but the Constitutional Convention by its judiciary report has abolished the Judges office, and he at once turns his talent to the wide newspaper field. We welcome the Progress to our exchange list, and predict for it a new era of prosperity and useful ness.

document.text: The following proposals by the Board of Directors were unanimous ly adapted during a mass meeting of contributors Wednesday even ing, November 7 First That the Christian Me morial Funds be used for the col lege education of the children of the late David A. Christian, III. Second Should the Christian Memorial Fund for some reason not be used for the education of the children of David A. Christian, III, then it is reoommended that the fund be made available as a loan fund to medical, dental, or nursing students who are citizens of Appo mattox County or adjoining coun ties. Third That the funds now on hand or that are later contributed be invested at the direction of the Board of Trustees in order that the funds anight produce an income until such time that they are used as sot forth m the first and second- recommendation. Dr. C. G. OBrien, chairman of the Board of Directors, points out that an expression f the wishes of donors was necessary because of in adequacy of the funds collected for the original objective. Any donor, not concurring in the proposals ol the Board of Directors as approved should call at the office of Dr. OBrien or W. C. Dudley, treasur er, before December 1.

document.text: The dramatic . trial of Frank Mayberry, 47 year old railway weld ers helper, of Evergreen, accused in the shot-in-the-dark killing of Dr. David A. Christian, III, on the night of Feb. 25, came to an end here late Saturday night, when a jury summoned from Cumberland County brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree with punishment fixed at imprison ment In the state penitentiary for life, f Mayberry was taken to Richmond -Monday to begin his term. Decision has not been made by his attorneys, W. F. Watkins, Jr., and J. B. Wall, Jr., of Farmyille, as to an apepal of the conviction nor has a decision been announced by the Commonwealth as to prose cution of a second indictment, charging the murder of Mayberrys brother-in-law, Jack Tucker. The trial began Friday morning and ended as midnight approached Saturday. The court room was pack ed during most of the two days, pnd the case attracted wide publici ty. High-water mark of the trial came when Mayberry took the stand to testify, and in a calm, quiet man ner declared, I feel mighty bad about it. For myself, and for the doctors family, and my people. The Story of the Trial At 1005 A. M. Friday, the sheriff, D. T. Robertson, brought the defendant, Frank Mayberry, into court, before a crowded courtroom. At 1008, the sheriff opened court, and at 1010, there was a delay a- waiting the arrival of George Ab- Continued on Page Nine

document.text: The Dr. David A. Christian, III, Memorial Fund has been increased by a 792.06 contribution from the employees of the Appomattox Gar ment Company. One hundred and eighty envelopes, containing dona tions from this number of individual employees was turned over to W. C. Dudley, treasurer of the fund, Tues day afternoon. It is understood that other employees have made pledges to swell the total Garment Company contribution to this project. Commenting on the fine support of the Memorial Fund effort, by the Appomattox Garment Company and its employees, C. T. Moses, Jr., the chairman of the fund raising com mittee said, This is an outstanding example of what can be done to achieve our goal. The Appomattox Garment Company employees ap proached this drive in an organized manner. Each employee was given an opportunity to make a definite pledge to the Memorial. A goal wa3 set as to the amount to be collect ed. We are indeed grateful for their support. It is understood that total pledges at the Appomattox Garment Com pany amounted to over 1,000. and that the cash turned over Tuesday will be increased as the pledges are paid. The Christian Memorial Fund was set up here shortly after the tragic shooting and the death of young Dr. Christian when on a mercy call to Evergreen in late February. The

document.text: The Christian family is unique in that so many of its members have been associated with the medical profession. His grandfather, the late Dr. Wm. D. Christian, was a be loved doctor. His son, Dr. David A. Christian, III, is a doctor. A daugh ter, Mrs. Harold Thompson, is a former medical technician. Another daughter, Miss Cathryn Christian, is a medical technician at the Medical College of Virginia. And another daughter, Miss Jpice OhrtMian, is a pre-medical student Wellesley College. His newphew,. Thomas Jennings, is a senior a,t the Medical College of Virginia, and Dr. Jen nings wife ns a doctor. The late Dr. Wm. Albert Thornhill was a be loved physician, of Charleston, W. Va., and he was a double first cou sin of Dr. Christian. And, Dr. Wm. Albert Thornhill, Jr. is practicing in Charleston. Another cousin was the late Dr. Carroll James, of White Plains, N. Y. Other more distant kinsmen have followc 1 the medical profession. Among members of Dr. Christ ians family here and who will at tend the ceremony Saturday, are  Mr. and Mrs. George Koos, Jr. and two daughters, Kristin and Cathryn, of Tangent, Oregon! Mrs. Harold Thompson, and daughter, Sue Ann, of Natick, Mass. Miss Joice Christ ian, a student at Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass. Mrs. Worth Har ris, of LaCross, Florida Lt. J. G. and Mrs. David A. Christian, III, and daughter, Mary Kathryn, of Quantico, Va. Dr. Christian, III is stationed at the Marine Base Miss Cathryn Christian, of Richmond, and Chesley Christian, of Appomattox. Others expected from out f Mrs K. H. Sisson, Mrs. J. H. Eld er, Mrs. Edwin Pauli, Mr. and Mrs. Bob Wheeler, Mrs. Wesley Higgins, Mrs. J. H. Elder, Jr. and two sons, all of Richmond Mr. and Mrs. S. B. Gilliam, of Dillwyn Mr. and Mrs. Parks Jennings, of Stonewall Mr. and Mrs. Tom Christian, of Cov ington, and William J. Byerly, II, of Winston-Salem, N. C. All those who desire to join in this testimony to a beloved citizen are urged to be present promptly at 300 P. M. this Saturday at the court house.

document.text: The Appomattox Chapter of the American Red Cross makes an ap peal for at least 50 walk-ins to come to Liberty Baptist Church base ment tomorrow, Friday, Oct. 30, and give a pint of blood. The chapter will fall short of the 135 pint quota unless others who have not already signed blood donor pledge cards give. Dr. David A. Christian, III, local physician issued this statement to day in making an appeal for blood donors The Red Cross Bloodmobile will visit Appomattox again on Friday, Oct. 30, between the hours of 1100 A. M. and 500 P. M., in the base ment of Liberty Baptist Church. The cessation of active conflict in Korea does not lessen the need for blood by the Red Cross. Appomattox being a participating County in the Red Cross Blood Bank program has made it possible for citizens of this county to receive hundreds of pints of blood free. One

document.text: some bf his old company yester day. They were taken from Battery and put into active service in the fight near Drewrys Bluff. Two were killed, Nathan Wright and William Hardin, and three were wounded. Charles Phelps, and David Abbitt and another one I do not remember his name. David Abbitt was serious ly wounded through the shoulder. I have not heard from Overtons company for over two weeks at last account they had not left their battery, I think. Brother George mentioned in our letter about Jim mie Featherstons horse being shot from under him while he was fol lowing General Hill. Capt. Adams captured a little Yankee Negro a few days ago. He was waiting on a Yankee orderly sargent of the north and when they left our front, he was left asleep. He is a smart little fellow about 11 years old and from his account has been in the service for three years. Jessie has been sick, but has recovered. I most of our Corps here have been sick have had the Diarrhoea slightly. Jimmie Featherston expects to get a detail to come home and get a horse he may possibly get it I think it doubtful. I think that you all might write twice a Week, while this campaign  last, for a week seems to me as long as a month generally is. Write every opportun ity. I will send this letter the first opportunity. Brother Georg  is off duty as a eourier. I have written al I could think of that would be at all interesting. Write as soon as you receive this short scroll. Your Affectionate Son, David A. Christian.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: School Officials Given Presents. Joseph D. Eggleston and R. C. Stearnes, the outgoing and incoming Superintendent of Public Instruc tion of Virginia, were presented with handsome tokens of regard by mem bers of the department and its allied activities. A loving cup was the pres ent handed Mr. Eggleston, while for Mr. Stearnes a gold-headed cane was the portion. The retiring superintend ent, just back from Washington, was opening his mail and setting his house in order for final withdrawal, while the new official was receiving mes sages and letters of congratulation. Then the entire office force descended upon the twain, who were forced to stand up and take their medicine. Judge David A. Christian, the office statistician and acting secretary to the State Board of Education, spoke up first. Regretting in the beginning that he did not possess the eloquence of a Cicero or Demosthenes, Judge Christian left those worthies not far behind. He referred to the work done by Mr. Eggleston in the office, but leaving this phase to the future his torian, he dwelt upon the affection felt by the subordinates  for the man who now becomes National Supervisor of Rural Schools. In conclusion he pre sented the beautiful loving cup to Mr. Eggleston, who responded as well as he could under affecting circum stances.

document.text: Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Tucker Me- Dearmon, wife of Clarence Stickley MeDearmon, died Tuesday at her home here after an illness of about three years. She was born at Nysalta, in Am herst County, the daughter of the late John Wilbur Fiske Tncker and Mary Richard Smith Tucker. She at tended schools in Amherst County and the Gooch School in Danville. She was a member of Memorial Methodist Church. Besides her husband, she is sur vived by three sons, James Wilbur and C. Lewis MeDearmon, of Appo mattox, and John Richard Tucker MeDearmon, of Richmond three daughters, Mrs. Frances McD. Cheat ham, of Appomattox Mrs. Sam B. Witt, Jr., of Fichmond, and Miss Mildred MeDearmon, of Columbia, S. C. and five grandchildren. Funeral services were held Wed nesday at 330 P. M, at the resi dence. Burial was in Liberty Ceme tery. Active pallbearers were Dr. David A. Christian, HI Claude W. Smith, J. A. Burke, Robert Doss, S. L. Ferguson, Jr. Harry MeDear mon, Floyd A. Porter and Walter Tucker, Jr.

document.text: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Koos, Jr., Route 1, Box 189, Tangent, Oregon, announce the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Adele Koos, to Rich ard Orrie Cundiff, son of Richard R. Cundiff, Bishop, California, and Mrs. Bilie Cundiff, Los Angeles. Miss Koos is a graduate of Albany Union High School, Albany, Oregon, and the University of Oregon, Eugene, Oregon. She is now employed as a Social W orker for the Veterans Administration in Eugene. Mr. Cundiff graduated from Franklin High School, Los Angeles, California, and is currently attending the Uni versity of Oregon, Eugene, Oregon. The wedding will be held in the First United Methodist Church, Lebanon, Oregon, at 730 p.m. on Saturday, Decem ber 28,1974. Miss Koos is a granddaugh te r of the former Dr. and Mrs. David A. Christian, Jr. of Appomattox.

document.text: LETTER LAUDS DR. CHRISTIAN Note Permission has been ob tained to publish the following let ter.  j Pamplin, Va, February 28, 1955. Dr. David A. Christian, Jr. Dear Dr. Christian, I must write this letter before another day is gone. Perhaps you consider this letter as one coming from the entire population of the little town of Pamplin and the sur rounding community. My vocabulary and education are far too limited to properly express the deep feeling of loss suffered by the tragic death of Dr. David, III. Everyone who had ever been ac quainted with him either socially or professionally loved him. His daily life and the practice of his profession was a shining example of witnessing for Christ. His was a life of service, daily practicing to the letter the Hippo cratic Oath. Many times he was called to out town, and always he came willingly and quickly, giving to all his pro fessional skill and kindness, re gardless of race, color or creed. His serene manner brought order out of chaos to many homes, and when nothing more could be done he left comfort and courage in those homes. This must have stem med from a deep abiding faith in God. I am a graduate nurse R. N. and became well acquainted with him. Often he sent patients to me for medicine or treatment which I could give, thus saving time and money for many of his patients who other wise might have had to wait until his busy schedule gave him time to come to them. Whatever our questions may be as to why death came to him in the way it did, I feel he died doing what he had always done, giving loving unselfish service to his fellow man. Im sure the Master said, Well done, when He welcomed Dr. David home. I never had the pleasure of meet ing Mrs. Christian socially, but I am very sure God will take her hand and yours, and give His loved ones the strength and help you will need in the long hours ahead. You must have been a wonderful father to have had such a fine son My husband, family and all the people here join me in this expres sion of sympathy. Sincerely, Mrs. Richard F. Williams

document.text: It was announced here this morn ing that Dr. David A. Christian, III will be released by the U. S. Navy within the next ten days, in order that he might return to his practice at Appomattox. Dr. Christian was called back to the U ! , a year ago, and is stationed now at Quantico, Va. Appomattox has experienced a serious medical problem during re cent months, and the shortage of doctors and great need for addition al practicianers, led local citizens to seek the release of Dr. Christian from the Navy.

April 9th Surrender Scene Described by Eye-Wi Un Editors note We are pleased to publish below an eyewitness descrip tion of the Surrend.-r at Appomat tox, written by Judge David A. Christian, father of Dr. D. A. Christ ian, 11. April 9, 1865 There are days in all of our lives in which scenes occur that impress themselves indelibly upon our mem ory, some of joy, some of sorrow. Purely the ninth of April 1865 was one of those days. At its recurrence each year our minds eye goes back to that ever memorable day and re views the scenes that then occurred. This scribe, though then only a boy in his teens, was one of the 8,000 soldiers that surrendered his musket on that occasion, and well does he remember the feeling of despair that filled his bosom when the dreadful news came that General Lee had sent forward the flag of truce and was negotiating the terms of surrender. Every hope that had brought him to the heroic struggle for liberty, was then thought forever gone. Oh, how vividly do we remember seeing our dearly beloved Lee coming back on his noted war horse Traveller and bringing the sad, sad news that he had surrendered. As he approached, his old soldiers gathered around him, soldiers of all ages and conditions of life, from boys in their teens to the old wrinkled veterans, from men who bore the proudest names in our Southland to those who could not even write their own names but who clung to their beloved leader with no less devotion, all bound together as one man by a common cause, a common love for their countrv, those

document.text: Funeral services for Dr. David Alexander Christian, Jr., 75, who died at his home here at 530 A. M. Friday, were conducted Monday at 330 P. M. from the Liberty Baptist Church. Burial was in the Christian family cemetery near Vera. The beloved veteran physician had been in declining health for some months, but had remained active and had ministered to patients in recent weeks, both at his home office and calls to .their homes. Horn in Appomattox County, he was the son of the late Judge David A. Christian and Mrs. Agnes Thorn hill Christian. He attended South side Chase City Academy and grad uated from the Medical College of Virginia in 1908. The same year, he began the practice of medicine in Appomattox and continued until his death. In 1916, he married Miss Bessie Stratton, who died in 1944. He was a member of New Hope Baptist Church, of Monroe Masonic Lodge, American Medical Associa tion and American Association of Railway Surgeons. His grandfather was the late Dr. William D. Christian, who for many years attended to the medical needs of the community. His father was the late Judge of Appomattox Cir cuit Court. He is survived by five daughters Mrs. George L. Koos, Jr., Tangent, Oregon Mrs. Harold E. Thompson, Jr., Aelxandria Mrs. Worth Harris, Lacrosse, Florida Mrs. William J. Byerly, Richmond Mrs. John _E. Cox Jr., South Swansea, Mass. one son, Chesley Stratton Christian, Appomattox two sisters, Mrs. G Parks Jennings, Appomattox, and Mrs. K. H. Sisson, Richmond one brother, Thomas L. Christian, of Covington and 14 grandchildren. Funeral services were conducteij by Dr. 0t A. Collins Jr., the Rev Charles Addington andthe Rev. ,W M. Thompson. Pal-bearers were Joel W. Flood, Harold Spencer, Chas. T Moses, Jerry Burke, J. A. Bingham Charlie Lewis, Wilson Thor.ihill and Walker OBrien.

document.text: FUND STILL GROWNG The fund raising drive for  the Dr. David A. Christian III Memor ial is progressing with sustained in terest. W. C. Dudley, fund treasur er, stated this week that a number of contributions had been received from Roanoke and vicinity as a re sult of an article in the Roanoke daily newspaper. The memorial is planned to honor the beloved local physician who was murdered while in the line of duty Feb. 25. The plan calls for a medical center building here. The fund has a goal of 20,- 000, and the project now has some 6,000 in cast and pledges.

document.text: Editors note We are indebted to Dr. D. A. Christian Jr., for the privilege of publishing the follow ing letter, written by his father on May 9, 1864, from Mechansville to his parents. David A. Christian was the son of Dr. W. D. Christian and his wife Lucy Christian, who was a daughter of David Bailey Patteson. This letter is only one of the many treasured documents in the collection of Dr. Christian, and this paper and its readers are al ways appreciative of the opportuni ty to read this material. -Editor. Dear Parents I wrote home a few days ago while our Army was around Hanover Court Junction. We have since mov ed down here within 2 miles of Mechanicsville and 8 miles north of Richmond, Va. I do not know any thing about where we are go ing. We stopped here last night. Probably we may leave here this evening or we may stay here sev eral days, I can not tell. Our Army came down parallel with the Yan kees. I think this move of General Grants is equivalent to an acknowl edgement of defeat. He has certain ly failed to carry out his first pro gramme. He has now, I suppose, adopted the plans of McClellan. He may think he can take Richmond like he did Vicksburg but he will find quite a different man from Peimbertan to interpose his pro gress To change the subject very much. I saw Charles Wingfield day before yesterday. He is as usual complain ing and when I saw him was hunt ing a hosptal. He says Bob Wing field is well. Brother George saw

document.text: Dr. David A. Christian, III, was elected president of the Appomat tox IPTAY Club, at a meeting held last Friday evening at the Ap pomattox High School auditorium The meeting was called for the purpose of nominating and electing officers. The nominating committee was composed of Hugh Brown, Mrs Louise T. Brown, Mrs. H. C. Pulliam T. T. Martin and Charles Thomas. The following officers were nomi nated and elected President, Dr. D. A. Christian, III Vice president, John S. Grinels. Secretary and treasurer, Burke Guill. Directors were named as follows Judge J. W. Flood, football. Mrs. H. W. Runkle, summer pro gram. R. M. Ferguson, basketball. Ned Hancock, baseball. The president appointed the fol lowing committees membership, Charles Thomas, chairman, and Ver- nell Mitchell. Special activities, Mrs. H. C. Pulliam. The new club takes its name from the words, I Pay Ten a Year  the membership fee being ten dol lars a year contributed to aid the athletic and recreational program at Appomattox High School.

document.text: Dr. C. G. OBrien has released the following statement to the people of the county I realize that all of us are sad dened by the untimely death of our beloved Dr. David A. Christian, III. And what we say will not relieve this empty feeling we have. He was more than a close friend and a physician to me because he gave me much inspiration in our daily con tact. And the only comfort that I can get is in my faith in the Heaven ly Father. I am sure He must have a better place for him. We have never received into our midst a duplicate of David Christian. But we are trying to contact some physi eian that would be interested in iO eating here. And until we do get help, I beg of you to continue to give me your cooperation. And if you will be patient, 1 will see all that call me for medical aid. My office office will continue 10 A. M. to 12 Noon, and 4 to 6 P. M., everyday, Wednesday in cluded and Sundays at 9 A. M. I will not remain in my office on Sunday after I finish seeing patients that are there at 9 A. M. C. G. OBrien, M. D.

document.text: Christian Memorial Fund Proposals are A dopted The following proposals by the Board of Directors were unanimous ly adopted during a mass meeting of contributors Wednesday even ing, November 7 first That the Christian Me morial Funds be used for the col lege education of the children of the late David A. Christian, 1H. Second Should the Christian Memorial Fund for some reason not be used for the education of the children of David A. Christian, III, then it is recommended that the fund be made available as a loan fund to medical, dental, or nursing students who are citizens of Appo mattox County or adjoining coun ties. Third That the funds now on hand or that are later contributed be invested at the direction of the Board of Trustees in order that the funds might produce an income until such time that they are used as set forth in the first and second recommendation. document.text: At a meeting of the Board of Di rectors and Advisors of the Christian Memorial Fund, it was recommend ed that a meeting be called of all those who contributed to the fund and all other i nterested persons. This meeting has been scheduled for Wednesday, Nov. 7, 1956, at 730 P. M., The meeting will be held in the Court House at Appo mattox. The purpose of the meeting is to consider ways and means of manag ing the funds now on hand and oth er funds that may be contributed. The following proposals are re commended First That the Christian Memor ial Funds be used for the education of the children of the late David A. Christian, IH. Second Should the Christian Me morial Fund for some reason not be used for the education of the chil dren of David A. Christian, III, then it is recommended that the fund be made avaialble as a loan fund to medical, dental, or nursing students who are citizens of Appomattox County or adjoining counties. Third That the funds now on hand or that are later contributed be invested at the direction of the Board of Directors in order that the funds might produce an income un til such time that they are used as set forth in the first and second re commendations. All interested persons are urged to attend and bring their friends t this call meeting on Nov. 7, 1956, at 730 P. M., -g Appomattox Court House.

document.text: At a called meeting of the Appo mattox town council last night, C. F. James was appointed to serve the two-year term as mayor begin ning now. G. B. Buchanan had been elected to this office by the voters in June, but did not qualify, having instead been appointed to serve out  an unexpired term as county treas urer. David A. Christian, III, was appointed to the vacancy on the council created by the appointment of James as mayor. C. T. Moses, Jr. was appointed council president.

document.text: Arrangements were virtually complete today for the Appomattox Cir cuit Court to meet its Friday date for trial resulting from the widely- publicized shooting spree at Evergreen on the night of February 26, when two men fell dead and the countryside was thrown into panic from as yet unexplained motives. A jury has been summoned from Cumberland County to hear the case of Commonwealth vs Frank Mayberry. Mayberry, 48, is accused of shooting to death his brother-in-law, Jack Tucker, and then shooting Dr. David A. Christian, III, popualr young Appomattox physician, who had gone to the Evergreen home on an errand of mercy. The case

document.text: An oil portrait of the late Dr. David A. Christian, III, will be un veiled in the Appomattox County Court House at 200 P. M., Friday, November 23. The following tribute to the late physician was written by a friend Future generations, who could not have known him, will gaze upon this portrait and ask this question Who was this young man? The most complete answer possible to that question is and will foe, He was a Christian. A Christian in name long dear to the citizens of this community the fourth generation of these Christian public servants consisting of three physicians and a judge. A large volume could be written about the tireless, generous and compassionate public services ren dered by each of these four men

document.text: Americans have lavished honors, medals, citations, ribbons, pensions, and many other honors and titles upon the herios of WAR. We have neglected the heroes of PEACE. Currently, there is discussion of how the nation might honor Dr. Salk, for his contribution to the de feat of paralysis from polio. He merits something more than a stack of editorials. In Appomattox, a worthwhile movement is under way to build a memorial to the late Dr. David A. Christian, III. The Times-Virginian does not be lieve in the democracy of establish ing in America of titles such as Sir. Lord, Duke, Count and Baron. But we do believe in suitable honors for the HEROES OF PEACE who have contributed to the GOOD of man kind. This concept should be ad vanced.
